title: 112_hr3332
content: The Act titled "Truth in Government Accounting Act of 2011" requires accurate financial statements. The "Truth in Government Accounting Act of 2011" mandates agencies to submit quarterly and annual consolidated financial statements based on fair-value accrual accounting method, including future liabilities and expenditures. Quarterly statements must be submitted within 90 days after the end of the fiscal quarter. Each annual financial statement required by the "Truth in Government Accounting Act of 2011" must be submitted within 180 days after the end of the fiscal year. The statements should adhere to generally accepted accounting principles and include footnote disclosures. The Comptroller General is required to publish these financial statements on a searchable, downloadable website accessible to the public within 10 days of submission. The Comptroller General audits agency consolidated financial statements annually in accordance with auditing standards. Agencies must provide all records and property for this purpose. The Comptroller General audits agency consolidated financial statements annually under the Truth in Government Accounting Act of 2011. Each agency must provide necessary facilities for the audit to be carried out effectively. The President and the Office of Management and Budget are required to prepare budgets using accrual accounting procedures in addition to the cash basis accounting method. Zero-baseline budgeting is also implemented. Changes in the Baseline: Amendments are made to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985, including excluding certain resources and eliminating adjustments for inflation. No adjustment for inflation shall be made for any direct spending program. The second sentence of section 275(b) of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to exclude subsections (a) through (d) of section 257. The Act and its amendments will be effective on October 1, 2012.
